org.numenta.nupic.network

Class Network

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.numenta.nupic.network.Network

  • public class Network
extends java.lang.Object

    A Network is the fundamental component of the HTM.java Network API. It is comprised of Regions which are in turn comprised of Layers; each Layer directly containing one or more algorithm or computational components such (i.e. Sensor, MultiEncoder, SpatialPooler, TemporalMemory, CLAClassifier etc.)

    Networks in HTM.java are extremely easy to compose. For instance, here is an example of a network which contains everything: 

     Parameters p = NetworkTestHarness.getParameters();
 p = p.union(NetworkTestHarness.getNetworkDemoTestEncoderParams());
 
 Network network = Network.create("test network", p)
     .add(Network.createRegion("r1")
         .add(Network.createLayer("1", p)
             .alterParameter(KEY.AUTO_CLASSIFY, Boolean.TRUE)
             .add(Anomaly.create())
             .add(new TemporalMemory())
             .add(new SpatialPooler())
             .add(Sensor.create(FileSensor::create, SensorParams.create(
                 Keys::path, "", ResourceLocator.path("rec-center-hourly.csv"))))));

    As you can see, Networks can be composed in "fluent" style making their declaration much more concise. While the above Network contains only 1 Region and only 1 Layer, Networks with many Regions and Layers within them; may be composed. For example: 

     Connections cons = new Connections();
 
 Network network = Network.create("test network", p)
     .add(Network.createRegion("r1")
         .add(Network.createLayer("1", p)
             .add(Anomaly.create())
             .add(new TemporalMemory())
             .add(new SpatialPooler())))
     .add(Network.createRegion("r2")
         .add(Network.createLayer("1", p)
             .using(cons)
             .alterParameter(KEY.AUTO_CLASSIFY, Boolean.TRUE)
             .add(new TemporalMemory()))                    
         .add(Network.createLayer("2", p)
             .using(cons)
             .add(new SpatialPooler())
             .add(Sensor.create(FileSensor::create, SensorParams.create(
                 Keys::path, "", ResourceLocator.path("rec-center-hourly.csv")))))
         .connect("1", "2")) // Tell the Region to connect the two layers Region.connect(String, String).
     .connect("r1", "r2");   // Tell the Network to connect the two regions connect(String, String).
    As you can see above, a Connections object is being shared among Region "r2"'s inner layers via the use of the Layer.using(Connections) method. Additionally, Parameters may be altered in place without changing the values in the original Parameters object, by calling Layer#alterParameter(KEY, Object) as seen in the above examples.

    Networks can be "observed", meaning they can return an Observable object which can be operated on in the map-reduce pattern of usage; and they can be subscribed to, to receive Inference objects as output from every process cycle. For instance: 

     network.observe().subscribe(new Subscriber<Inference>() {
      public void onCompleted() { System.out.println("Input Completed!"); }
      public void onError(Throwable e) { e.printStackTrace(); }
      public void onNext(Inference i) {
          System.out.println(String.format("%d: %s", i.getRecordNum(), Arrays.toString(i.getSDR())));
      }
 });

    Likewise, each Region within a Network may be "observed" and/or subscribed to; and each Layer may be observed and subscribed to as well - for those instances where you would like to obtain the processing from an individual component within the network for use outside the network in some other area of your application. To find and subscribe to individual components try: 

     Network network = ...
 
 Region region = network.lookup("<region name>");
 region.observe().subscribe(new Subscriber<Inference>() {
     public void onCompleted() { System.out.println("Input Completed!"); }
     public void onError(Throwable e) { e.printStackTrace(); }
     public void onNext(Inference i) {
         int[] sdr = i.getSDR();
         do something...
     }    
 }
 
 Layer l2_3 = region.lookup("<layer name>");
 l2_3.observe().subscribe(new Subscriber<Inference>() {
     public void onCompleted() { System.out.println("Input Completed!"); }
     public void onError(Throwable e) { e.printStackTrace(); }
     public void onNext(Inference i) {
         int[] sdr = i.getSDR();
         do something...
     }    
 }
    In addition there are many usage examples to be found in the org.numenta.nupic.examples.napi package where there are tests which may be examined for details, and the NetworkAPIDemo
    Author:
    David Ray
    See Also:
    Region, Layer, Inference, ManualInput, NetworkAPIDemo

      Connects the specified source to the specified sink (the order of processing flows from source to sink, or lower level region to higher level region).

      Returns the top-most (last in execution order from bottom to top) Region in this Network

      Returns the current Network.Mode with which this Network is currently configured.

      Returns the String identifier for this Network

      Returns the network-level Parameters.

      Returns the encoder present in one of this Network's Sensors

      Returns a reference to the Region which contains the Sensor
      Region getTail()
      Returns the bottom-most (first in execution order from bottom to top) Region in this Network
      void halt()
      Halts this Network, stopping all threads and closing all SensorFactory connections to incoming data, freeing up any resources associated with the input connections.
      java.util.Iterator<Region> iterator()
      Returns a Iterator capable of walking the tree of regions from the root Region down through all the child Regions.
      Region lookup(java.lang.String regionName)
      Returns the Region with the specified name or null if it doesn't exist within this Network
      <any> observe()
      Returns an Observable capable of emitting Inferences which contain the results of this Network's processing chain.
      void pause()
      Pauses all underlying Network nodes, maintaining any connections (leaving them open until they possibly time out).
      void reset()
      Finds any Region containing a Layer which contains a TemporalMemory and resets them.
      void resetRecordNum()
      Resets the recordNum in all Regions.

      Sets the MultiEncoder on this Network

      Sets the reference to this Network's Sensor
      void setSensorRegion(Region r)
      Sets a reference to the Region which contains the Sensor (if any).
      void start()
      If Network.Mode == Network.Mode.AUTO, calling this method will start the main engine thread which pulls in data from the connected Sensor(s).

      • getName

        public java.lang.String getName()
        Returns the String identifier for this Network
        Returns:

      • start

        public void start()
        If Network.Mode == Network.Mode.AUTO, calling this method will start the main engine thread which pulls in data from the connected Sensor(s). Warning: Calling this method with any other Mode than Network.Mode.AUTO will result in an UnsupportedOperationException being thrown.

      • halt

        public void halt()
        Halts this Network, stopping all threads and closing all SensorFactory connections to incoming data, freeing up any resources associated with the input connections.

      • pause

        public void pause()
        Pauses all underlying Network nodes, maintaining any connections (leaving them open until they possibly time out). Does nothing to prevent any sensor connections from timing out on their own.

      • getMode

        public Network.Mode getMode()
        Returns the current Network.Mode with which this Network is currently configured.
        Returns:

      • reset

        public void reset()
        Finds any Region containing a Layer which contains a TemporalMemory and resets them.

      • resetRecordNum

        public void resetRecordNum()
        Resets the recordNum in all Regions.

        Returns the bottom-most (first in execution order from bottom to top) Region in this Network

      • iterator

        public java.util.Iterator<Region> iterator()
        Returns a Iterator capable of walking the tree of regions from the root Region down through all the child Regions. In turn, a Region may be queried for a Iterator which will return an iterator capable of traversing the Region's contained Layers.
        Returns:

      • compute

        public <T> void compute(T input)
        Used to manually input data into a Network, the other way being the call to start() for a Network that contains a Region that contains a Layer which in turn contains a Sensor -OR- subscribing a receiving Region to this Region's output Observable.
        Parameters:
        input - One of (int[], String[], ManualInput, or Map<String, Object>)

      • computeImmediate

        public <T> Inference computeImmediate(T input)
        Used to manually input data into a Network in a synchronous way, the other way being the call to start() for a Network that contains a Region that contains a Layer which in turn contains a Sensor -OR- subscribing a receiving Region to this Region's output Observable.
        Parameters:
        input - One of (int[], String[], ManualInput, or Map<String, Object>)

      • addDummySubscriber

        private void addDummySubscriber()
        Added when a synchronous call is made and there is no subscriber. No Subscriber leads to the observable chain not being constructed, therefore we must always have at least one subscriber.

      • connect

        public Network connect(java.lang.String regionSink,
                       java.lang.String regionSource)
        Connects the specified source to the specified sink (the order of processing flows from source to sink, or lower level region to higher level region).
        Parameters:
        regionSink - the receiving end of the connection
        regionSource - the source end of the connection
        Returns:
        this Network
